Subject: Maximising Histories (aka Causal Entropic Forcing)
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=344770077; y=tyFaPla7Hr5Ow-jR0hPvhrSVa_ml95FM456f8ElyFfZVITR3Ixb0
X-Yahoo-Profile: alienseedpod

This paper got good reasonably good coverage this week:

   [Causal Entropic Forces]
   http://www.alexwg.org/publications/PhysRevLett_110-168702.pdf

I skimmed the paper as I found it difficult to read, but the core
concept is to do with agents within some problem domain that operate
by trying to preserve as many 'future histories' as possible, or in
other words - attempt to keep as many options open as possible.

I thought it was worth mentioning here as it seems similar in concept
to novelty (objective free) searching, that is, there is no explicit
objective defined apart from not performing actions that would limit
the set of future action pathways (e.g. jumping off a cliff). For a
given problem domain the set of option preserving actions is usually
fairly narrow in relation to all possible actions, so the resulting
agents (if they are able to preserve options) will inevitably
demonstrate something akin to intelligent behaviour.

I'd be interested in others' take on this. This idea that intelligence
is related to entropy is not entirely new so I'm not quite sure what
new ideas this paper offers (if any). What are good methods for
measuring (or estimating) future history preservation? (entropy). I
have some initial ideas but I'll leave it at that for now.

Colin
